您使用的是过时的浏览器。它可能无法正确显示此网站或其他网站。您应该升级或使用其他浏览器。我读过很多关于 AP 的帖子，但它失败了等等，但我坚持了过去 2 年，并认为对它的特殊性有所了解。主要挑战是幻影制动，学会注意桥梁，经过的卡车，道路上的波峰，迎面而来的车辆急转弯，偶尔无缘无故地减速并迅速踩下油门以避免跟车（无疑是几个'为什么不幸的追随者会想到那个布偶刹车的想法）。然而今天发生的事情意味着我放弃了。沿着 A 路笔直行驶，我前面没有车辆，后面几乎没有汽车（所有人都保持距离，即感谢上帝没有尾随）。左边的路有一辆车耐心地等待加入 A-Road - 在我看来，不要太向前引发“幻影制动”。下一件事是完全紧急制动，系紧安全带把风吹倒了我 - WTF !!!这真是太危险了，嗨，伙计。我现在有几次这样的经历，我学会了期待它并向前踩踏板。您目前是哪个软件版本？我已经注意到至少它在我 2021.4.18.11 更新后开始发生。感觉就像他们改变了雷达灵敏度。嗨，伙计。我现在有几次这样的经历，我学会了期待它并向前踩踏板。您目前是哪个软件版本？我已经注意到至少它在我 2021.4.18.11 更新后开始发生。感觉就像他们改变了雷达灵敏度。 2021.4.18.2 我必须说，我从 3 月份开始才拥有这辆车，我的想法也很相似。我只在主要的双车道上使用 AP/NoA，并且只在较大的道路上使用 TACC，在那里我可以预测会发生什么。如果没有一些幻影制动事件，我无法单次上下班（往返约 55 英里），通常是侧面摄像头或传感器看到我们已经在旁边的东西并决定紧急制动。出于这个原因，我只在非常清楚的时候使用 TACC，并在有任何可能会扰乱它的时候停用它。有一个例子，一辆从另一边驶来的汽车离道路的中心线太近了，TACC 认为太近了，紧急刹车。好在我接手很快，跟在我身后的人并没有靠的太近，不然的话那是TACC垃圾一塌糊涂造成的事故。我真的希望这与他们在视觉和雷达之间遇到的困难有关，而仅使用视觉的新 FSD 堆栈将解决这些问题。我只能希望。我只能说“只有视觉”堆栈不能更糟。真正让我烦恼的是它在过去 2 年里变得越来越糟 - 备受赞誉的 OTA 更新，不要认为这个想法是定期自动地使功能变得更糟。我开始想念我的梅赛德斯和它的驾驶飞行员 - 它比 6 年前的这个 cr*p 效果更好
然而今天发生的事情意味着我放弃了。沿着 A 路笔直行驶，我前面没有车辆，后面几乎没有汽车（所有人都保持距离，即感谢上帝没有尾随）。左边的路有一辆车耐心地等待加入 A-Road - 在我看来，不要太向前引发“幻影制动”。下一件事是完全紧急制动，系紧安全带把风吹倒了我 - WTF !!!这简直太危险了 [更新] 在撰写本文时，OP 的评论并未表明他们仅使用了 Autopilot 的 TACC 子集。这篇文章是基于当引用术语 Autopilot 时，它指的是 Autopilot 的全部功能，即 TACC 和 Autosteer（除了安全功能）。因此参考手册中的 Autosteer 约束。尽管这篇文章与 TACC 无关，但我将重点介绍影响完整 Autopilot/Autosteer 功能的用例约束。这听起来正是不应使用自动驾驶仪/自动转向的道路类型——它不受入口和出口坡道的限制。如果在不使用的情况下使用自动驾驶仪/自动驾驶仪，那么它有时会以未定义的方式执行。我也在 2021.4.18.2（我似乎不再获得软件更新，自上一次以来已经有很长的差距）并且正如我多次向该小组发表评论时，我遇到了与您刚刚描述的完全相同的经历。上一次在 A1 上行驶时，在接近一辆等待驶出加油站的汽车时引发了猛烈的撞击和几乎弄脏裤子的事件。幸运的是没有人紧随其后。正如我之前评论过的，这是 Autopilot 最新版本的一个严重错误，特斯拉需要解决这个问题，因为它确实存在潜在危险。也就是说，我最近在高速公路上使用 FSD 的体验非常非常好。数百英里的舒适驾驶，换道和处理合并交通的工作非常好。所以我还没有把婴儿和洗澡水一起倒掉。对我来说，真正令人沮丧的是特斯拉在按照承诺部署可靠的 FSD 功能方面的进展速度比宣传的要慢得多，尤其是在美国以外。此外，在 Elon 广泛报道的推文中，软件功能取得了巨大进步的无益声称似乎从未交付过。 YouTube 上新的 FSD beta V9 视频确实展示了一些令人印象深刻的进步并展示了系统的真正潜力，但它们也突出了许多遗留的问题和错误，以至于我们很难清楚地知道我们何时可以访问这里是对真正有用的 FSD 版本的重大升级，不仅仅是高速公路驾驶，这几乎证明了我提前支付的标价是合理的。尽管如此，希望还是永恒的......这就是为什么这些道路不打算与 Autopilot 一起使用。我们中的许多人不时这样做......在我自己的情况下只是为了测试技术的进展情况，如果可能的话，我总是比正常驾驶时更加小心和关注。我已经超越了极限，看看在某些情况下它是否真的会驶离道路边缘......（是的，是的，并且在 A 路上）......但我不会声称特斯拉的失败，因为他们已经告诉我不要这样做！当然，双车道是另一回事。在其操作环境之外使用任何工具都是危险的。将您的体验归结为用户错误。在 NoA 上，我在外面的车道上一个空的 d/c。一辆汽车从出口匝道中途汇入内侧车道。我通过了它，然后刹车来了。我已经提前进入o/s车道，让另一辆车加入。 NoA 可用的事实意味着正确使用 AP。事后刹车。完全不能接受。幸运的是，我的脚总是在那些场合盖住油门。我在 4.18.11，它比 4.18.3 更糟糕。汽车太靠近路缘石并且太靠近 l/h 弯道上的白线 这听起来正是不应使用自动驾驶仪/自动转向的道路类型 - 它不受入口和出口坡道的限制。如果在不使用的情况下使用自动驾驶仪/自动转向，那么它有时会以未定义的方式执行。查看附件 686175 查看附件 686176
不太确定引用手册的 Autosteer 部分有什么作用，我完全了解 Autosteer 的限制和推荐使用。这不是我有问题的自动转向，我认为它是交通感知巡航控制，根据我对手册的阅读，允许在 A 道路上使用。我完全理解“这是测试版”，但我的观点仍然存在。根据我的经验，在我深思熟虑的观点中，过去两年情况变得更糟，甚至变得危险。所以我将停止使用它，我 6 年前的前车可以做得更好。不太确定引用手册的 Autosteer 部分有什么作用，我完全了解 Autosteer 的限制和推荐使用。这不是我有问题的自动转向，我认为它是交通感知巡航控制，根据我对手册的阅读，允许在 A 道路上使用。我完全理解“这是测试版”，但我的观点仍然存在。根据我的经验，在我深思熟虑的观点中，过去两年情况变得更糟，甚至变得危险。所以我将停止使用它，我 6 年前的前车可以做得更好。我同意。我已经对它失去了所有的信心，并尽可能避免使用它。我唯一一次使用它是在高速公路上从头到尾的交通。我发现 TACC 上的幻影制动和 AP 上一样经常和多事。不幸的是，没有选择只能保持速度的愚蠢巡航控制系统。还是我错过了那个设置？我们家的另一辆车是 ICE Corsa，我使用这种愚蠢的巡航比使用 TACC 多。正如其他人评论的那样，当您保持平衡时，它会让您更加专心，准备好跳上快速踏板，以防汽车在经过的阴影处摇晃。我发现自己很少使用 AP 或 TACC，压力太大了！可悲的是，其他汽车在自适应巡航控制方面做得很好，例如我妻子的基本款高尔夫。只是有效 - 保持您设定的速度或按照您设定的距离跟随前面的汽车。并且在各种道路上。我已经遇到过几次，虽然这不是我最大的抱怨，但可能不是严格的 AP，但我一点也不相信显示的速度限制。我有 40 in 60, 60 in 40, 70 in 50, 70 in 60（单车道所以不可能是 70）等等。所以即使我信任 TACC，我也不能相信它的速度是正确的。我也在 2021.4.18.2（我似乎不再获得软件更新，自上一次以来已经有很长的差距）并且正如我多次向该小组发表评论时，我遇到了与您刚刚描述的完全相同的经历。
左边的路有一辆车耐心地等待加入 A-Road - 在我看来，不要太向前引发“幻影制动”。我在 2021.4.18.11 上，我的现在也在这样做（不确定这改变了哪个版本，但最近）。没有理由，另一辆车不在路上，只是在一个路口等着，自动驾驶仪出于某种原因将其视为威胁，并在您通过路口时猛踩刹车。我不认为这是“幻影制动”，对我来说这意味着在未知情况下制动。相反，在这里我们可以确切地看到汽车制动的原因，但它根本不应该这样做。不确定这是否是另一个被忽视的右手驱动错误（否则这肯定会被其他人报告在这里？），但它很危险，应该尽快修复。同样在 2021.4.18.2，并且现在（在过去一个月左右）两次出现这种不必要的中断，但幸运的是没有线程启动器那么戏剧化。我的第一个例子是在 A90 的双车道部分，另一辆车正等待从一条几乎垂直的侧路加入 - 视野清晰，没有明显向前爬行，但靠近我的左侧车道。第二个例子是类似的，但我没有那么惊讶，可能会更快地踩下加速器来中止刹车。根据手册猜测，我不应该在双车道上使用自动转向，除非它们实际上是具有适当交叉点的高速公路……这会真正减少苏格兰的公用事业。请注意，这已在此处标记，以便特斯拉将其视为可能的 RHD/英国特定问题，请竖起大拇指，以帮助特斯拉确定优先事项。我最近在恶劣的天气里从贝兹开车到朴茨茅斯。然后桑坦德到赫罗纳，阳光充足。一个全开幻影刹车，一个在旅途中退缩。使用 FSD 运行 4.18.11（我该死的更新在哪里？！？！？）大约 90 pc NoA。快乐的露营者......油漆很好，没有面板间隙，只是回到 SC 更换了道路危险轮胎（这是在回家的路上）。天啊。我的经验：特斯拉的自动驾驶仪并不比之前梅赛德斯的巡航控制系统灵敏。不像左边的任何东西暗示系统“某事”可能会发生。大多数情况下，当车辆等待从左侧的侧转弯向右转时，也会出现左转车辆的滑道。它比梅赛德斯更好，因为我可以设置我和前面汽车之间的距离。但是当它发现一个行人从右到左横穿马路时，我紧急停车，它忽略了有行人避难所的事实，并假设这个人会跑在汽车前面。不好玩。除了在高速公路上缓慢行驶之外，自动转向毫无意义。我不期望自动驾驶，除了在高速公路上，会在我的有生之年发生（我 69 岁）最近我从克劳利到利物浦又回来了……FSD 一直活跃（除了环形交叉路口），没有问题……快乐的！

 I've read many a thread regarding AP and it's failing etc, but I persevered for the last 2 years, and thought had a handle on it's peculiarities.  Main challenge was phantom braking, learnt to watch out for bridges, passing lorries, crest's in road's, sharpish turns with oncoming traffic, occasional sporadic slow down for no apparent reason and pressed accelerator promptly to avoid freaking out following traffic (no doubt a few 'why is that muppet braking' thoughts by the unfortunates following).  However what happened today means I give up.  Travelling down straight A-Road, no traffic in front of me, few cars behind (all keeping their distances i.e. no tailgating thank god). Road on left has a car patiently waiting to join A-Road - Not to far forward to provoke 'phantom braking' in my view. Next thing full emergency braking and the wind knocked out of me by seatbelt tightening - WTF !!!!  This is just bloody dangerous
 Hi mate. I had this now a few times and I learn to expect it and step the pedal ahead. Which software version you are at the moment? I have noticed for me at least it started happening after I updated at 2021.4.18.11. It feels like they change something on the radar sensitivity.
 Hi mate. I had this now a few times and I learn to expect it and step the pedal ahead. Which software version you are at the moment? I have noticed for me at least it started happening after I updated at 2021.4.18.11. It feels like they change something on the radar sensitivity.
2021.4.18.2
 I must say, I’ve only had the car since March and I’m of a similar mind. I only use AP/NoA on major dual carriageways and only use TACC on larger roads where I can predict what’s going to happen. I can’t go a single trip to work and back (around 55mi round trip) without some phantom braking event, usually where a side camera or sensor sees something that we’re already next to and decides to emergency brake. For that reason, I only use TACC when it’s pretty clear, and deactivate it when there’s any chance of anything upsetting it. Had one instance where a car coming the other way got a bit too close to the central line in the road and TACC decided that was too close and emergency braked. Fortunately, I took over pretty quickly and the person behind me wasn’t too close, otherwise that would’ve been an accident caused by TACC being utter rubbish. I’m really hoping this is all to do with the difficulties they’ve had between vision and radar and the new FSD stack using only vision will solve these issues. I can but hope.
 All I can say is 'vision only' stack can't be worse. What really annoys me is it has been getting worse over the last 2 years - so much the much lauded OTA updates, don't think the idea was to regularly make a feature worse and automatically at that.  I'm beginning to miss my mercedes and it's drive pilot - It worked better than this cr*p and that was 6 years ago
 However what happened today means I give up.  Travelling down straight A-Road, no traffic in front of me, few cars behind (all keeping their distances i.e. no tailgating thank god). Road on left has a car patiently waiting to join A-Road - Not to far forward to provoke 'phantom braking' in my view. Next thing full emergency braking and the wind knocked out of me by seatbelt tightening - WTF !!!!  This is just bloody dangerous
  [update] At time of writing, the OP's comment gave no indication that they were using just the TACC subset of Autopilot. This post was made on the basis that when the term Autopilot is referenced, it refers to the full capabilities of Autopilot, ie TACC & Autosteer (in addition to the safety features). Hence references to Autosteer constraints from manual. Even though this post is not relevant to TACC, I will leave it be to highlight the use case constraints that do affect full Autopilot/Autosteer functionality.  This sounds to be precisely the type of roads where autopilot/autosteer should not be used - it is not limited by entry and exit ramps. If autopilot/autosteer is used in circumstances where it is not for use, then from time to time it is going to perform in an undefined way.
 I am also on 2021.4.18.2 (I don't seem to be getting software updates any more, has been a long gap since last one) and as I commented to this group several times I have had exactly the same experience you just described. Last time was driving along on the A1 when approaching a car waiting to pull out of a petrol station induced a violent slam-on and near trouser soiling event. Fortunately nobody close behind.  As I commented before, this is a serious bug with recent versions of Autopilot and Tesla need to fix this as it is indeed potentially dangerous. That said, my recent experience with FSD on the motorway was really, really good. Hundreds of miles of comfortable driving with lane changing and dealing with merging traffic working really well. So I am not throwing the baby out with the bath water just yet.   The real frustration here for me is the much slower than advertised rate of progress with Tesla in getting reliable FSD features deployed as had been promised, especially outside of USA. Also, the unhelpful claims of wonderful progress with software features in Elon's widely reported tweets that never seem to be delivered. The new spate of FSD beta V9 videos on YouTube definitely show some impressive progress and tease the true potential of the system, but they also highlight so many remaining issues and bugs that it is hard to get any clear idea as to when we will get access here to a significant upgrade to a genuinely useful version of FSD for more than motorway driving that comes anywhere close to justifying the sticker price I paid in advance. Still, hope springs eternal...
 That's why those kind roads are not intended to be used with Autopilot. Many of us do it from time to time ... in my own case just to test how things are going with the tech and invariably I am applying even more care and attention than when driving normally, if that's possible. I've pushed beyond the limits to see if it really would drive off the edge of the road in some circumstances ... (yes it does, yes and on an A road   ) ... but I'm not going to claim a fail on Tesla's part because they already told me not to do it! Dual carriageways are, of course, a different matter.
 Using ANY tool outside its operating environment will be dangerous. Put your experience down to user error.
 On NoA, I was in the outside lane on an empty d/c. a car merged from the off ramp partway Into the inside lane. I passed it and then the brakes came on. I’d moved into the o/s lane well ahead to allow the other car to join. the fact that NoA was available implies correct use of AP. Braking after the event. Completely unacceptable. Luckily my foot is always covering the accelerator for just those occasions. I’m on 4.18.11 and it’s worse than 4.18.3. Car too close to kerbs and too close to the white line on l/h bends
 This sounds to be precisely the type of roads where autopilot/autosteer should not be used - it is not limited by entry and exit ramps. If autopilot/autosteer is used in circumstances where it is not for use, then from time to time it is going to perform in an undefined way.   View attachment 686175 View attachment 686176
Not too sure what quoting the Autosteer section of the manual does,  I'm fully aware of the limitations and recommended use of Autosteer. It's not autosteer I have a problem with, I assume it's traffic aware cruise control, which based on my reading of the manual is allowed for use on A Roads.  I fully understand 'it's beta', but my point remains. Based on my experience, It's got worse in the last two years to the point of being dangerous, in my considered opinion. So I will stop using it and my previous car 6 years ago could do a better job.
 Not too sure what quoting the Autosteer section of the manual does,  I'm fully aware of the limitations and recommended use of Autosteer. It's not autosteer I have a problem with, I assume it's traffic aware cruise control, which based on my reading of the manual is allowed for use on A Roads.  I fully understand 'it's beta', but my point remains. Based on my experience, It's got worse in the last two years to the point of being dangerous, in my considered opinion. So I will stop using it and my previous car 6 years ago could do a better job.
I agree. I’ve lost all faith in it and avoid using it wherever possible. The only time I use it is in nose to tail traffic on motorways.
 I find phantom braking on TACC as regular and eventful as on AP. Unfortunately there's no option to have a dumb cruise control that just holds your speed. Or have I missed that setting?   The other car in our house is an ICE Corsa and I use that dumb cruise more than I use TACC. As someone else commented it makes your more attentive as you are poised, ready to jump on the fast pedal in case the car throws a wobbly at a passing shadow. I find myself rarely using AP or TACC, it's just too stressful!
 The sad thing is that other cars do adaptive cruise control so well, for example my wife’s basic Golf. just works - keeps the speed you’ve set or follows the car in front at the distance you’ve set. And on all kinds of roads.
 I've had that a couple of times although its not my biggest gripe, may not be stricktly AP but I don't trust the displayed speed limits one bit. I've had 40 in 60, 60 in 40, 70 in 50, 70 in 60 (single carriageway so could never be 70) etc. So even if I trusted TACC, I can't trust it to be doing the correct speed.
 I am also on 2021.4.18.2 (I don't seem to be getting software updates any more, has been a long gap since last one) and as I commented to this group several times I have had exactly the same experience you just described.
 Road on left has a car patiently waiting to join A-Road - Not to far forward to provoke 'phantom braking' in my view.
 I'm on 2021.4.18.11 and mine is now doing this too (not sure what version this changed, but quite recent). There is no reason for it, the other car is not on the road, is merely waiting at a junction, and autopilot for some reason sees this as a threat and slams on the brakes as you pass the junction.  I don't think this is "phantom braking" as such, to me that implies braking for unknown circumstances. Instead, here we can see exactly why the car is braking, but it simply should not be doing it.  Not sure if this is another right hand drive bug that has crept in unnoticed (otherwise this would surely be reported by others more here?), but it is dangerous and should be fixed asap.
 Also on 2021.4.18.2, and had this unwanted breaking twice now (in the last month or so), but thankfully not as dramatic as the thread starter.  My first example was on a dual carriageway section of the A90, another car waiting to join from a near perpendicular side road - had a clear side on view, wasn't obviously creeping forward but was close to my left hand lane.  Second example was similar, but I was less surprised, and probably pressed the accelerator quicker to abort the breaking.  Guess as per the manual I shouldn't be using auto steer on dual carriageways unless they are actually motorways with proper junctions... which would really cut down on the utility here in Scotland.  Note this has been  flagged here for Tesla to look into as a possible RHD/UK specific issue, please go give that a thumbs up in case that helps Tesla prioritise things.
 I recently drove from Beds to Portsmouth in foul weather. Then Santander to Girona in full sun. One full-on phantom brake, one flinch on the trip. Running 4.18.11 with FSD (where's my damn update?!?!?) About 90pc NoA. Happy camper... paint fine, no panel gaps, only been back to the SC to replace a road hazarded tyre (it was on the way home). YMMV.
 My experience:   Tesla's Autopilot is no more, or less, sensitive than Cruise Control on the previous Mercedes. Neither like anything on the left which suggests to the system "something" might happen. Mostly it is when a vehicle is waiting to turn right from a side turn on the left, but also when there is a slip lane for cars turning left. It is better than the Mercedes as I can set the distance between me and the car in front.  BUT I had a full blown emergency stop when it spotted a pedestrian crossing the road from right to left, it ignored the fact that there is a pedestrian refuge and assumed that the person would run in front of the car. Not fun.   Autosteer is pointless, other than driving slowly in traffic on a motorway.   I have no expectation that autonomous driving, other than on a motorway, will happen in my lifetime (Im 69)
 Recently I had a trip from Crawley to Liverpool and back... FSD active always (except roundabouts) and no issues... Happy!
title: 特斯拉 AutoPilot – 我放弃了，它是彻头彻尾的致命
title_en: Tesla AutoPilot – I give up, it's downright lethal

欢迎来到涂鸦冠军岛游戏！在接下来的几周里，加入 calico (c)athlete Lucky 探索 Doodle Champion Island：一个充满七个运动迷你游戏、传奇对手、数十个大胆的支线任务和一些新朋友（和老朋友）的世界。她的终极目标？击败每位运动冠军以收集所有七个神圣卷轴——并在嗡嗡声中完成冠军岛的额外隐藏挑战。你是猫科动物 Lucky 😼 吗？点击今天的涂鸦，加入四个颜色团队之一，为实时全球排行榜做出贡献，让游戏开始吧！了解今天与东京动画工作室 STUDIO 4°C 合作制作的交互式 Doodle 的幕后花絮！明天再来看看 Lucky，查看实时团队排行榜，并观看 Doodle Champion Island Games 中展开的动作！您的 Calico (C) 运动员：Lucky 以 Lucky 的身份参加冠军岛运动会——您最喜欢的新猫科动物。运动 |乒乓球传奇冠军|天狗与这只淘气的猛禽打乒乓球滑板传奇冠军|狸猫展示你最疯狂的空中动作来击败这个变形的骗子
运动 |射箭传奇冠军| Yoichi 瞄准快速准确地超过这位武士将军和专家射手 Sport |橄榄球传奇冠军 | Oni Dart，俯冲并躲避这些可怕的敌人以达到您的目标艺术游泳传奇冠军|当您访问这个冠军的水下王国时，如果您的节奏是坚定不移的，那就去乙姬海公主吧 Sport |攀登传奇冠军| Fukuro 攀登到山顶，但要避开这个能出勺子的猫头鹰冠军的障碍。马拉松传奇冠军| Kijimuna Outsprint 这些活泼的树精，不要让疯狂的甲壳类动物放慢您的脚步 Doodle Champion Island Games 的过场动画和角色由日本东京动画工作室 STUDIO4°C 创作。下面他们分享了他们制作这个 Doodle 背后的想法： 问：你能告诉我们你对 Doodle 中每个角色进行改编的创作过程吗？
首先，我在全国范围内搜索了出现知名度高的人物和明星人物的故事和民间故事。接下来，我铸造了与游戏中使用的事件内容相关的古老故事和角色。然后，在设计上，每一位眼睛冠军都取自一个独特的故事，将日本随处可见的河童、八重流、舞狮等东西变成了团队领导和城市里的人。在原有的故事和画面的基础上，我们扩展了适合游戏的元素。首先，我们找出了来自全国各地的故事和民间故事，以及具有较高知名度的人物。接下来，我们将这些民间故事和人物与游戏中包含的每个体育赛事联系起来。在设计过程中，每个赛事冠军都是从这些人物中选出的。团队吉祥物和城市中的角色，如河童，八重流，舞狮，也是因为他们在日本非常有名，每个角色的设计都是根据他们原来的故事形象，然后改编成游戏毕竟，忍者猫Lucky虽然很酷也很可爱，所以它是“推”的！
此外，可以描绘从北海道到南方的冲绳的各种故事，可以描绘水下和热带沙滩、森林和雪山等各种舞台，尽可能地传达日本多样化的自然景观尽可能。如果可以，我会很高兴。既酷又可爱的幸运忍者猫绝对是最喜欢的一个方面！我们很高兴我们能够在 Doodle 中提及从北海道到南部的冲绳的各种故事。在日本广为人知的我们还希望传达这个国家丰富多样的自然美景，包括水下、热带沙滩、森林和雪山。问：你们的团队有没有最喜欢的人物或运动出现在 Doodle 中？然后我喜欢 Koma 狗.既然是狮子，那一定是野兽，但既然变成了妩媚的角色，我对它的感觉就很强烈。
守护犬扮演着神社看门人的角色，但我认为让他在游戏中充当向导很有趣。另外，天狗和乒乓球的组合在真正的古老传说中是不可能的，但我认为这是一个很好的组合，因为它符合有扇子和轻巧移动的天狗的性质。角色：石头守卫。他们可能有点吓人，因为他们是狮子，但我们喜欢他们在游戏最终设计中的迷人之处。我们认为他们在日本文化中充当守门人的事实让他们很有趣运动：乒乓球！天狗和乒乓球的组合在传统的民间故事中是不常见的，但我们认为这是一个合适的组合，因为天狗拿着扇子，动作很快。我想要​​你先享受游戏本身，我希望你能通关到最后，但主角挑战的东西以鲜花和饺子的形式给大家带来了快乐，这是冠军。只有知道了。
换句话说，我想传达一种精神，即每个人的辛勤工作，没有人知道，导致每个人的幸福。我要三色饺子热潮来！首先，我们希望大家喜欢这款游戏并坚持到最后！同时也希望通过完成小游戏，Lucky 以鲜花和团子的形式带来幸福……这将是对世界上每个人的一种享受！另外，只有冠军知道Lucky有多努力。换句话说，我们想传达的是，我们每个人的专注和努力会带来快乐，而这并不总是被其他人认可。我们也希望有一个三色团子（三个) 彩色饺子) 趋势 :) Mark Ivey、Eric Arnold、Daniel Dovali、David Lu、Audrey LoVan、Conner Lane、Jacob Katzeff、Jacob Howcroft、Kathy Lee、Stephanie Gu、Leah Sandacz、Jonathan Shneier 导演、故事板、角色设计师和主要动画 | 田中隆弘导演/孔蒂/角色设计/原创 | 田中隆弘 CGI 导演、合成和编辑 | 稻叶雅也 CGI 导演/拍摄/剪辑 | 稻叶雅也艺术指导和背景 | 赤木久子（Orange Co., Ltd.）艺术总监/背景 | Toshiko Akagi (Orange Co., Ltd.)
色彩造型师&色彩协调师 | 高桥若子色彩设计/色彩设计 | 高桥若子中间人 | 中泽美友、原口千春、REVOROOT、qIXIE STUDIO、studio Hibari Osaka studio、STUDIO GIMLET、STUDIO MASSKET、STUDIO / MOO、MSC、StudioL、 OLM Asia Video | 中泽快斗、原口千春、Revolt、qIXIE STUDIO、Studio Kujaku Osaka Studio、Studio Gimlet、STUDIO MASSKET、Studio Mu、MSC、Studio El、OLM Asia Desital Ink & Paint | D-COLORS、studio step、Defa、 MSC, STUDIO MASSKET, Jumondou Finishing | D-COLORS, Studio Step, Defer Co., Ltd., MSC, STUDIO MASSKET, Jumondo Legal & Coordinator | Ayumi Inoguchi 法律事务/翻译 | Ayumu Inoguchi 动画助理制作人 | Sayuri Yoshiyama, Moruto Yamashita制作进度 | 吉山小百合、山下凑动画制作人 | 荻原智子动画制作人 | 荻原知子
note_en:
Welcome to the Doodle Champion Island Games! Over the coming weeks, join calico (c)athlete Lucky as she explores Doodle Champion Island: a world filled with seven sport mini-games, legendary opponents, dozens of daring side quests, and a few new (and old ;)) friends. Her ultimate goal? Defeat each sport Champion to collect all seven sacred scrolls—and complete extra hidden challenges across Champion Island in the purrr-ocess.
  Are you feline Lucky 😼 ? Click on today’s Doodle, join one of the four color teams to contribute to the real-time global leaderboard, and let the games begin!
      Go behind-the-scenes of today’s interactive Doodle, made in partnership with Tokyo-based animation studio,     STUDIO 4°C!
      Come back tomorrow to keep up with Lucky, check the real-time team leaderboard standings, and watch the action unfold in the Doodle Champion Island Games!
        Your Calico (C)athlete: Lucky    Compete in the Champion Island Games as Lucky—your new favorite feline.
        Sport | Table Tennis     Legendary Champion | Tengu   T   ake a shot at table tennis against this mischievous bird of prey
            Sport | Skateboarding      Legendary Champion | Tanuki       Show your gnarliest aerial moves to beat this shapeshifting trickster
          Sport | Archery     Legendary Champion | Yoichi     Aim quickly and accurately to outscore this Samurai general and expert marksman
        Sport | Rugby     Legendary Champions | The Oni     Dart, dip, and dodge these fearsome foes to reach your goal
              Sport | Artistic Swimming     Legendary Champions | Princess Otohime     Sea if your rhythm is unWAVEring when you visit this champion’s underwater kingdom
          Sport | Climbing     Legendary Champion | Fukuro     Scale to the mountain top, but avoid the obstacles from this ladle-yielding owl champion
        Sport | Marathon      Legendary Champions | The Kijimuna   Outsprint these spry tree spirits, and don’t let the crazy crustaceans slow you down
                                        The cutscene animations and characters for Doodle Champion Island Games were created by Tokyo, Japan-based animation studio,  STUDIO4°C. Below they share their thoughts behind the making of this Doodle:
    Q. Can you tell us about your creative process for adapting each of the characters in the Doodle?
  まず、認知度が高く、スター性のある登場人物が出て来る物語や民話を、全国各地から探しました。
  次に、ゲームに使用される種目内容と結びつく昔話やキャラクターをキャスティングしました。
  そして、デザイン化において、各種目チャンピオンは固有の物語から採り、
  河童や八咫烏、獅子舞など日本のあちらこちらにあるものを、チームリーダーや街の人々にしました。
  それぞれ、元々のお話やイメージをベースにしたうえで、ゲームに合った要素を膨らましていきました。
  First, we identified stories and folktales from all over the country with characters that are highly recognized. Next, we connected those folktales and characters with each of the sport events included in the game. In the design process, each event champion was selected from those unique stories. The team mascots and the characters in the city such as Kappa, Yatagarasu, lion dance, were also chosen as they are very well known across Japan. Each character’s design was based on their original story image, but then adapted for the game.
      なんと言っても、忍者猫ラッキーが、かっこいい中にも可愛らしさがあって‘推し’です！
  また、北は北海道から南は沖縄まで色々な物語を題材にできたことで、
  海中や南国の砂浜、森や雪山など様々な舞台を描くことができ、
  日本の多彩な自然観を少しでも伝えられたら嬉しいです。
  Lucky the Ninja Cat, who is both cool and cute, is definitely a favorite aspect!
  We're pleased that we were able to allude to various stories from Hokkaido in the north to Okinawa in the south in the Doodle. Besides drawing inspiration from stories known across Japan, we also hoped to convey the rich and diverse natural beauty of the country, including underwater, sandy tropical beaches, forests, and snowy mountains.
    Q: Does your team have any favorite characters or sports that appear in the Doodle?
  キャラクターでは狛犬が気に入っています。獅子ですから猛獣のはずなんですが、愛嬌のあるキャラになったので思い入れが強いです。
  狛犬は神社のゲートキーパーの役割をしているのですが、ゲーム的にも案内役にしてもらえて面白く仕上がったと思います。
  また、天狗と卓球を組み合わせたのは、本当の昔話の中ではありえないことですが、
  団扇を持っていて軽やかに移動する天狗の性質とマッチして、良い組み合わせだと思います。
  Character: The stone guardians. They can be a bit scary given that they’re lions, but we love how charming they are in the game’s final design. We think the fact that they serve as gatekeepers in Japanese culture made it interesting to have them serve as guides in the game.
  Sport: Table tennis! The combination of Tengu and table tennis is not something you'd find in the traditional folktale, but we think it was a fitting combination given the nature of the Tengu, who holds a fan and moves swiftly.
      ゲーム自体の勝負をまずは楽しんで欲しい、是非最後までクリアして欲しいのですが、
  主人公が挑んできたことは、皆にお花と団子という形の幸せをもたらして、そのことはチャンピオンだけが知っている。
  つまり、誰も知らない一人一人の頑張りが、皆の幸福につながっている、という精神性を伝えたいです。
  そして、三色だんごブームが来て欲しいです！
  First, we hope people enjoy the game and make it to the end! But also convey that by completing the mini games, Lucky brings happiness in the form of flowers and dangos…which will be a treat to everyone in the world! Also, only Champions know how hard Lucky worked. In other words, we want to convey that joy can result from the focus and hard work of every one of us, which is not always recognized by others. We’re also hoping for a sanshoku dango (three colored dumplings) trend :)
          Mark Ivey, Eric Arnold   ,   Daniel Dovali, David Lu, Audrey LoVan, Conner Lane, Jacob Katzeff, Jacob Howcroft, Kathy Lee, Stephanie Gu, Leah Sandacz, Jonathan Shneier

随着美国面临第四波 Covid-19，亚马逊仓库工人表示，该公司正在通知他们员工中的病例数量不断增加。同时，该公司正在放松口罩政策，并在月底关闭现场免费检测。一位亚马逊员工经常在达拉斯-沃斯堡国际机场的一家工厂培训新员工，并要求匿名，因为她不允许向媒体发表讲话，许多员工都在无视规则。她说，有些人戴着口罩来参加她的培训，但没有接种疫苗。但她看到他们后来摘下了口罩。她说，与此同时，她所在的大楼里的病例也在增加。她想知道她未接种疫苗的同事是否可能会在她的工作场所无意中传播 Covid。 “有几个月的干旱期，”这位女士说，指的是她从亚马逊收到的自动电子邮件，其中披露了新的 Covid 病例……“但它正在回升。” NBC 新闻查看了该公司本月发送的几封电子邮件，以通知其达拉斯-沃斯堡机场设施中的 Covid 阳性病例。与美国大部分地区一样，亚马逊最近几个月开始放宽其工作场所规定。但与此同时，根据疾病控制和预防中心的数据，该国正面临由传染性 delta 变体引发的新冠病毒病例激增，几乎完全在未接种疫苗的人群中发现，尽管在一些罕见的情况下，接种疫苗的人仍然可能成为已感染。 NBC News 在全国范围内采访了 11 名亚马逊员工，他们表示他们担心自己的福利，希望在 delta 变体继续传播的同时更严格地执行口罩要求，并希望该公司继续进行现场 Covid 测试。 “这就是我们大多数人所担心的。他们正在解除一切，就好像他们不在乎是否有另一种变种，”巴尔的摩亚马逊工厂的一名工人说，他因害怕遭到报复而要求匿名。
“他们不在乎人们不必接种疫苗并且就在我们旁边工作。我们真的不知道该怎么办。我们正在尽最大努力，因为我们大多数人都有必须支付的账单。”近两个月以来，亚马逊已允许几乎所有工人在完全接种疫苗的情况下不戴口罩前往其运营中心。如果工人想要不戴口罩，他们需要通过将疫苗接种卡上传到称为“AtoZ”的内部工人应用程序来证明他们已经接种了疫苗。在亚马逊系统中注册疫苗接种记录后，应用程序中的数字背景颜色会发生变化。现在，亚马逊将逐步取消其大部分流行病协议，包括取消在其运营中心入口处进行温度检查、停止现场测试、终止其社会疏远执法人员以及要求所有人戴口罩雇员。亚马逊在 2 月份的年度报告中表示，它在 2020 年花费了 115 亿美元用于与 Covid 相关的成本。亚马逊发言人 Maria Boschetti 在一封电子邮件声明中表示，该公司确实“强烈鼓励”员工接种疫苗，每剂提供 40 美元，无论他们在哪里接种疫苗。她说：“随着我们的员工和社区继续接种疫苗以及卫生当局制定指南，我们正在不断评估我们为应对 COVID-19 实施的临时措施，并根据公共卫生当局的指南进行调整。” “因此，我们将在 2021 年 7 月 30 日之前开始减少我们在美国的测试业务。”她补充说，该公司将“始终将我们的安全协议与 CDC 和其他公共卫生官员的最新指南保持一致”，并且该公司“已准备好根据需要立即恢复我们的员工测试计划。” Boschetti 还分享了最近发给工人的信件，解释了公司如何以及为什么“恢复正常做法”，并再次重申“我们每个人都可以采取的最重要的安全措施是接种疫苗。”自大流行开始以来，亚马逊仓库的工人一直表达对他们安全的担忧，他们组织从纽约皇后区和史坦顿岛、纽约和芝加哥等地的仓库罢工，以抗议他们所说的缺乏保护的危险工作条件需要远离冠状病毒。
根据 NBC 新闻 3 月份的一项调查，许多在大流行期间公开反对工作缺乏安全并试图组织同事推动加强健康保护的工人声称遭到报复。该报告发现，在大流行期间，向国家劳工关系委员会提出的指控亚马逊干涉工人组织权利的指控数量增加了两倍多。 “我们对种族主义或任何形式的报复采取零容忍态度，在许多情况下，这些投诉来自对同事采取不当行为并因此被解雇的个人，”亚马逊发言人 Leah Seay 回应说。 “我们尊重员工加入、组建或不加入工会或他们自己选择的其他合法组织的权利，而不必担心遭到报复、恐吓或骚扰，”她说。亚马逊在 10 月份表示，其近 20,000 名仓库员工的 Covid 检测呈阳性。从那时起，该公司就没有提供最新的阳性病例数。亚马逊在美国雇佣了近 140 万人。但为了应对疫情爆发，该公司在 11 月表示，将通过“世界一流的实验室团队”对员工进行快速检测，在 650 个地点每天进行 50,000 次检测。亚马逊没有要求其仓库员工接受测试。乔纳森·贝利在纽约皇后区的亚马逊仓库工作，去年组织了一次罢工，抗议该公司涉嫌缺乏 Covid 保护措施，他证实最近几天他收到了一条消息，称亚马逊将在稍后结束其现场测试这个月。但他说，即使现在该设施提供 Covid 测试，亚马逊也很少鼓励他接受测试。他说：“有一次我的经理告诉我，'嘿，我们在凌晨 2 点进行测试，以防你想接受测试'，那是在整个大流行期间。”
其他工作人员表示，免费的现场测试非常方便，尤其是对于那些可能在奇怪的时间结束的长时间轮班工作的人来说。 “有很多员工轮班工作 10 小时，每周工作 50 到 60 小时，在现场进行测试比请假要容易得多，”一位在亚马逊工厂外面工作的女性说辛辛那提并要求保持匿名，因为她不允许向媒体发表讲话。 “我知道免费测试是广泛可用的。但这并不方便。我工作到凌晨 5 点，然后我必须做 [其他差事]。”几名工人说，他们看到戴口罩变得越来越松懈，尤其是当所谓的“安全巡逻”——专门负责加强社会疏远和戴口罩的重新定位的工人——在仓库里逐渐结束时。 38 岁的杰里米·拜伦 (Jeremy Byron) 在俄亥俄州托莱多 (Toledo) 郊外的一家亚马逊工厂工作，他说：“经理们可不是那样做的。” “我认为他们没有尽其应得地推动规则，如果他们这样做，就会推动疫苗接种。在我接种疫苗之前，我会亲自到我的岗位，我会摘下口罩，经理们从不说任何话。”据巴尔的摩工人说，除了不戴口罩外，一些未接种疫苗的工人还想出了其他方法，通过小偷小摸来规避规则。一旦工人证明他们已经接种了疫苗并更新了他们的数字记录，他们还会收到一个贴在身份证上的物理贴纸，作为他们已接种疫苗且不再需要戴口罩的视觉提示。
“我看到人们找到了贴纸卷并开始传递它们。没有人注意。所以他从办公桌上抓起一卷贴纸，”他说。“它并没有真正受到监控。”亚马逊经常向其履行中心和其他物流中心的员工发送自动电子邮件，提醒员工注意“个人” Covid 确诊病例。但整个大流行期间的员工都抱怨这些电子邮件缺乏针对性：它们只包含有关此人最后一次上班时间的信息，而没有说明他们在哪个班次或哪个部门工作。Facebook 的亚马逊员工团体和其他在线聚会场所已经比较了设施之间的记录，以了解全国范围内新爆发的地方。亚马逊自 10 月以来一直没有更新其感染统计数据，当时它表示自去年 3 月以来已有近 20,000 名员工感染了病毒。拉斯的工人拉斯维加斯和巴尔的摩在 NBC 新闻评论的私人 Facebook 群组中分享，他们在最近几周收到了多起阳性病例通知。这两个城市都是前据新闻报道，正在经历冠状病毒的激增。皇后区的员工贝利说，在他的工厂，亚马逊发出的 Covid 阳性病例的通知常常让人觉得被低估了。 “你不能相信提供给你的信息，因为亚马逊经常不传达案例。我们会发现那些生病的人，但没有关于它的通知，”他说。在回应 2020 年 9 月 NBC 新闻对亚马逊对其设施中 Covid 爆发缺乏透明度的调查时，发言人丽莎·莱万多夫斯基 (Lisa Levandowski) 表示，该公司向工人居住的卫生部门报告了工人中的所有阳性病例，但没有公布病例总数按设施分解，以避免造成“不必要的恐惧”。
“我们认为，共享病例数具有误导性，并且缺乏大量背景信息——例如每个人最后一次在现场的时间、现场所在社区的总体感染率、与员工居住地相关的社区数据，自大流行开始以来的时间表以及与其他公司相比的总体比率，”她说。其他工人想知道为什么有时需要很长时间才能将几个月前诊断出的感染情况告知员工。 “在消息中，它会说明这些员工最后一次出现在现场的时间，”史坦顿岛工厂的一名工人德里克·帕尔默 (Derrick Palmer) 说。这位 32 岁的纽约人去年因与大流行相关的担忧以及公司违反纽约法律和联邦健康指南的指控而起诉该公司。去年，亚马逊赢得了一项驳回动议，但帕尔默和其他原告的上诉正在联邦上诉法院审理。帕尔默说，本月他收到了他所在机构的阳性病例通知，称该人几个月前接受了检测。 “这没有意义。为什么[亚马逊]现在通知我们？”他说。与此同时，在达拉斯，根据该工人最近与 NBC 新闻分享的与 Covid 相关的工作电子邮件的统计，该工人从亚马逊收到的电子邮件中列出的报告病例激增。她的电子邮件显示，迄今为止，亚马逊已在 7 月的 10 天告诉当地工人，至少有一个确诊病例。这位女士说，6月份，只有三起确诊病例的报告。
同样，一名在圣路易斯以西的亚马逊工厂工作的 42 岁男子也要求保持匿名，他表示，截至 7 月，他收到了 18 起新病例通知，而 6 月份为 14 起。这似乎与圣路易斯大都市区的病例激增有关，当地卫生官员“强烈建议”重新戴口罩和保持社交距离。这位圣路易斯工人说，他因为新冠病毒失去了朋友，并说他“非常认真地对待这件事”。 “我每天都会收到这些 [通知]，几乎每天下午 6 点，”他说。 “这太疯狂了。” Cyrus Farivar 是旧金山 NBC 新闻技术调查部门的一名记者。 April Glaser 是旧金山 NBC 新闻技术调查小组的一名记者。
note_en:
As the nation faces a fourth wave of Covid-19, Amazon warehouse workers say the company is notifying them of a rising number of cases among employees. At the same time, the company is relaxing its mask policies and shutting down on-site free testing at the end of the month.
 According to one Amazon worker who regularly trains new employees at a facility at the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport and asked to remain anonymous because she’s not allowed to speak to the press, many are flouting the rules. She says that some people come to her training wearing masks and unvaccinated. But she sees them remove their masks later on.
   At the same time, she says, cases are on the rise in her building. She wonders if her unvaccinated co-workers may be inadvertently spreading Covid at her workplace.
 “There was a dry spell for a couple months,” the woman said, referring to the automated emails she’s received from Amazon that disclose new Covid cases.. “But it’s picking back up.” NBC News has viewed several of the emails the company sent this month to notify employees of positive Covid cases in its Dallas-Fort Worth Airport facility.
  Amazon, like much of America, has begun to relax its workplace rules in recent months. But at the same time, the nation is facing a new surge in Covid cases fueled by the infectious delta variant, found almost entirely among unvaccinated people,  according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, although in some rare cases vaccinated people can still become infected.
 NBC News interviewed 11 Amazon workers nationwide who say that they are concerned about their own welfare, want mask requirements to be more stringently enforced while the delta variant continues to spread, and for the company to keep its on-site Covid testing.
  “That’s what most of us are worried about. They’re lifting everything and it’s like they don’t care that there’s another variant out,” said one worker at an Amazon facility in Baltimore, who sought anonymity out of fear of reprisal.
 “They don’t care that people don't have to get a vaccine and are working right next to us. We really don’t know what to do. We’re doing our best because most of us have bills we have to pay.”
 For nearly two months now, Amazon has  allowed nearly all workers to come to its fulfillment centers maskless if they are fully vaccinated. If the workers want to be maskless, they are asked to demonstrate that they have been vaccinated by uploading their vaccination card to the internal worker app, known as “AtoZ.” Once the vaccination record has been registered in Amazon’s system, the digital background color changes in the app.
 Now Amazon  is set to wind down most of its pandemic protocols, including elimination of temperature checks at the entries to its fulfillment centers, the halting of on-site testing, ending of its social distancing enforcement crew, and the required wearing of masks for all employees. In its annual report in February, Amazon  stated that it spent $11.5 billion on Covid-related costs in 2020. Amazon spokesperson Maria Boschetti said in an emailed statement that the company does “strongly encourage” employees to be vaccinated, offering $40 per dose, regardless of where they receive a vaccination.
  “As our employees and communities continue to get vaccinated and health authorities evolve guidance, we are continuously evaluating the temporary measures we implemented in response to COVID-19 and making adjustments in alignment with public health authority guidance,” she said. “As a result, we will begin ramping down our U.S. testing operations by July 30, 2021.”
 She added the company would “always align our safety protocols with updated guidance from the CDC and other public health officials,” and that the company was “prepared to immediately resume our employee testing program as needed.”
 Boschetti also shared correspondence that was recently sent to workers, explaining how and why the company was “returning to normal practices,” and again reiterating that “the most important safety measure any of us can take is to get vaccinated.”
   Workers in Amazon warehouses have been voicing concerns about their safety since the start of the pandemic, organizing walkouts from warehouses in locations like Queens and  Staten Island, New York, and  Chicago in protest against what they said were hazardous working conditions that lacked the protection they needed to stay safe from the coronavirus.
  Many workers who spoke out against the lack of safety at work during the pandemic and attempted to organize their colleagues to push for stronger health protections claimed they were retaliated against, according to  an investigation by NBC News in March. That reporting found the number of charges filed with the National Labor Relations Board accusing Amazon of interfering with workers’ rights to organize more than tripled during the pandemic.
 “We have zero tolerance for racism or retaliation of any kind, and in many cases these complaints come from individuals who acted inappropriately toward co-workers and were terminated as a result,” Leah Seay, an Amazon spokeswoman, said in response.
 “We respect our employees’ right to join, form or not to join a labor union or other lawful organization of their own selection, without fear of retaliation, intimidation or harassment,” she said.
 Amazon  said in October that nearly 20,000 of its warehouse employees had tested positive for Covid. The company has not provided an updated number of positive cases since then. Amazon employs almost 1.4 million people in the United States.
   But to address its outbreaks, in November  the company said it was on pace to reach 50,000 tests per day across 650 sites with a “world-class laboratory team” to rapidly test workers. Amazon did not require its warehouse employees to get tested.
  Jonathan Bailey, who works at an Amazon warehouse in Queens, New York, and who organized a walkout over the company’s alleged lack of Covid protections last year, confirmed that he received an announcement in recent days that Amazon is ending its on-site testing later this month. But even with the Covid testing that is now offered at the facility, Amazon rarely encouraged him to get tested, he said.
 “There’s one time I had a manager tell me, ‘Hey, we’re doing testing at 2 a.m. in case you want to get tested,’ and that was over the entire pandemic,” he said.
 Other workers said that having free on-site testing was very convenient, especially for people who were working long shifts that can end at odd hours.
 “You have a lot of employees working 10-hour shifts, 50 to 60 hours a week, and it was a lot easier to get tested on site rather than take time off work,” said one woman who works at an Amazon facility just outside Cincinnati and asked to remain anonymous because she’s not allowed to speak to the press.
  “I understand that free testing is widely available. But it doesn't make it convenient. I work until 5 a.m. and then I have to do [other errands].”
   Several workers say that they have seen mask wearing get more lax, particularly as the so-called “safety patrol” — repurposed workers tasked specifically with enforcing social distancing and mask-wearing — winds down in warehouses.
  “The managers aren’t on it like that,” said Jeremy Byron, 38, who works at an Amazon facility outside Toledo, Ohio. “I don’t think they push the rule as much as they should and if they did that would push vaccinations. Before I got vaccinated, I personally would get to my station and I would take my mask off and managers never said nothing.”
  In addition to not wearing masks, some unvaccinated workers have figured out other ways to circumvent the rules by engaging in petty theft, according to the Baltimore worker.
 Once workers demonstrate that they have been vaccinated, and their digital records are updated, they also receive a physical sticker to put on their ID badge as a visual cue that they have been vaccinated and no longer need to wear masks.
 “I saw people that found the roll of stickers and started passing them around. Nobody was paying attention. So he grabbed a roll of stickers off of a desk," he said. "It’s not really monitored."
   Amazon has routinely sent out automated emails to employees at its fulfillment centers and other logistics hubs that alert workers of “an individual” who had a confirmed case of Covid. But employees throughout the pandemic complained that the emails lack specificity: they only contain information about when the person was last at work, and don’t say which shift or which department in which they worked.
  Amazon workers in Facebook groups and other online gathering places have compared notes across facilities to get a sense of where new outbreaks are happening nationwide. Amazon has not updated its infection statistics since October,  when it said that nearly 20,000 employees contracted the virus since last March.
  Workers in Las Vegas and Baltimore are sharing in private Facebook groups reviewed by NBC News that they’ve received multiple notifications in recent weeks of positive cases. Both cities are experiencing a surge in the coronavirus, according to  news  reports.
 Bailey, the Queens employee, said that at his facility, the notifications Amazon sends out of positive Covid cases often feel like an undercount.
 “You can’t trust the information that is given to you because Amazon very regularly doesn’t communicate cases. We will find out about folks who have got sick and yet there’s no notification that comes out about it,” he said.
  In response to a  September 2020 NBC News investigation into Amazon’s lack of transparency about Covid outbreaks in its facilities, spokeswoman Lisa Levandowski said that the company reports all positive cases among workers to the health department where the worker lives, but doesn’t release total cases broken down by facility to avoid creating “unnecessary fear.”
 “We believe that sharing a case count is misleading, and lacks a significant amount of context — like when each individual was last on-site, the overall infection rate in the community where the site is located, community data relative to where the associate lives, timelines since the start of the pandemic and the overall rate compared to other companies,” she said.
 Other workers wonder why it has sometimes taken a long time to inform employees of infections that were diagnosed months ago.
 “In the messages, it will say the last time that these associates were last on the site,” Derrick Palmer, a worker at the Staten Island facility, said.
  The 32-year-old New Yorker sued the company last year over pandemic-related concerns and allegations that the company violated New York laws and federal health guidance. Last year, Amazon won a motion to dismiss, but Palmer and the other plaintiffs’ appeal is pending before a federal appellate court.
 Palmer says this month he’s received notifications for positive cases at his facility that say the individual was tested months ago. “It doesn’t make sense. Why [is Amazon] informing us now?” he said.
   Meanwhile in Dallas, there has been a spike in reported cases listed in emails that the Dallas-Fort Worth worker has received from Amazon, according to a count of this worker’s recent Covid-related work emails that she shared with NBC News.
 To date, her emails show, Amazon has told local workers on 10 separate days in July that there was at least one confirmed case. In June, there were only three reports of confirmed cases, the woman said.
  Similarly, a 42-year-old man who works at an Amazon facility west of St. Louis, who also asked to remain anonymous, said that so far in July, he’s received 18 notifications of new cases, compared to 14 for June.
 That appears to track with a new spike in cases in the St. Louis metropolitan area, where local health officials are “ strongly recommending” masking and social distancing anew.
 The St. Louis worker said that he has lost friends to Covid and said he “takes it very seriously.”
 “I get those [notifications] daily, it’s almost every day at 6 p.m.,” he said. “This is crazy.”
 Cyrus Farivar is a reporter on the tech investigations unit of NBC News in San Francisco.
 April Glaser is a reporter on the tech investigations team for NBC News in San Francisco.
title: 亚马逊对工人的混合信息：病例增加，测试结束，口罩是可选的
title_en: Amazon's mixed message to workers: Cases are up, testing is over and masks are optional

note:
佛罗里达州卡纳维拉尔角（美联社）——火星上的地震测量装置首次提供了对这颗红色行星内部的详细观察，揭示了在寒冷表面下惊人的薄地壳和炽热的熔融核心。在本周发表的一系列文章中，科学家们报告说，火星地壳的厚度在地球的范围内。地壳和地核之间的火星地幔大约是地球的一半厚。火星的核心比科学家们预期的要高，尽管比我们自己的行星的核心要小，几乎是地球的两倍。这些新的研究证实火星的核心是熔融的。但根据国际研究小组的说法，需要更多的研究来了解火星是否有一个像地球一样的固体内核，被熔化的外核包围。这些发现是基于法国地震仪在 2018 年抵达火星的 NASA 洞察号固定着陆器上记录的大约 35 次地震。迄今为止，圆顶地震仪实际上已经检测到 733 次地震，但 35 次震级为 3.0 到 4.0 级作为基础对于这些研究。大多数相当大的地震起源于 1,000 英里（1,600 公里）外的火山区，那里的熔岩可能在数百万年前就曾流动过。参与地壳研究的美国宇航局喷气推进实验室的马克潘宁说，即使是最大的地震也非常微弱，地球上几乎感觉不到。他希望“大的”可以更容易地处理数据和定义火星内部。目前的测量显示，火星的地壳可能深达 12 英里至 23 英里（20 公里至 37 公里）；地幔向下延伸近 1,000 英里（1,600 公里）；以及半径为 1,137 英里（1,830 公里）的相对较轻的核心。相比之下，地壳的范围从海洋下方几英里（公里）到喜马拉雅山下方超过 45 英里（70 公里）。地球几乎是火星的两倍。
潘宁说：“通过从卡通理解火星内部的样子，把真实的数字放在上面……我们能够真正扩大理解我们的太阳系岩石行星是如何形成的家谱。” InSight 的使命又延长了两年，最近几个月遭遇了电力危机。灰尘覆盖了它的太阳能电池板，就在火星正在接近其围绕太阳运行的轨道上的最远点时。飞行控制器通过使用着陆器的机械臂将沙子释放到吹来的风中以去除面板上的一些灰尘，从而提高了功率。地震仪继续工作，但由于电力状况，所有其他科学仪器仍处于中断状态——除了一个德国热探测器在 1 月份未能在地球上挖出超过几英尺（半米）的地方后被宣布死亡。这三项研究和一篇配套文章发表在周四的《科学》杂志上。美联社健康与科学部得到霍华德休斯医学研究所科学教育部的支持。 AP 全权负责所有内容。
note_en:
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) — A quake-measuring device on Mars is providing the first detailed look at the red planet’s interior, revealing a surprisingly thin crust and a hot molten core beneath the frigid surface.
 In a series of articles published this week, scientists reported that the Martian crust is within the thickness range of Earth’s. The Martian mantle between the crust and core is roughly half as thick as Earth’s. And the Martian core is on the high side of what scientists anticipated, although smaller than the core of our own nearly twice-as-big planet.
 These new studies confirm that the Martian core is molten. But more research is needed to know whether Mars has a solid inner core like Earth’s, surrounded by a molten outer core, according to the international research teams.
   The findings are based on about 35 marsquakes registered by a French seismometer on NASA’s InSight stationary lander, which arrived at Mars in 2018. The domed seismometer has actually detected 733 marsquakes so far, but the 35 with magnitudes from 3.0 to 4.0 served as the basis for these studies. Most of the sizable quakes originated in a volcanic region 1,000 miles (1,600 kilometers) away where lava may have flowed just millions of years ago.
 Mark Panning of NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory, who took part in the crust study, said even the biggest marsquakes are so weak they would barely be felt on Earth. He’s hoping for “the big one” which would make it easier to process the data and define the Martian interior.
  Current measurements show Mars’ crust possibly reaching as deep as 12 miles to 23 miles (20 kilometers to 37 kilometers); the mantle extending down nearly 1,000 miles (1,600 kilometers); and the relatively lightweight core with a radius of 1,137 miles (1,830 kilometers).
 By comparison, Earth’s crust ranges from a few miles (kilometers) beneath the oceans to more than 45 miles (70 kilometers) beneath the Himalayas. Earth is almost double the size of Mars.
 “By going from cartoon understanding of what the inside of Mars looks like, putting real numbers on it ... we are able to really expand the family tree of understanding” how our solar system’s rocky planet formed, Panning said.
 Its mission extended by another two years, InSight has been hit with a power crunch in recent months. Dust covered its solar panels, just as Mars was approaching the farthest point in its orbit around the sun.
  Flight controllers have boosted power by using the lander’s robot arm to release sand into the blowing wind to knock off some of the dust on the panels. The seismometer has continued working, but all other science instruments remain on hiatus because of the power situation — except for a German heat probe was declared dead in January after it failed to burrow more than a couple feet (half a meter) into the planet.
 The three studies and a companion article appeared in Thursday’s edition of the journal Science.
  The Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute’s Department of Science Education. The AP is solely responsible for all content.
title: 火星上的地震测量装置详细观察红色星球的内部
title_en: Quake-Measuring Device on Mars Gets Detailed Look at Red Planet's Interior

note:
在柏林施特格利茨区一个不起眼的 1000 平方米工业单位的一楼，四名工人小心翼翼地将怀孕的蚁后放入试管中，以便将它们运送到整个欧洲。这是蚂蚁商店，世界上第一家专业蚂蚁商店，拥有大约两打员工的企业，一个玻璃切割车间，塑料和石膏模型工作室以及一名全职社交媒体经理。它只是柏林数量惊人的商店之一，只出售一种东西，无论是爬行的昆虫、咸味糖果、胶带还是微型弦乐器。随着在线零售改变世界各地城市大街的面貌，许多人想知道这种超专业化是否不仅仅是德国首都动荡历史的偶然副作用，也是未来大街的蓝图。由于一系列危机使欧洲面临压力，一些城市正在以创新的解决方案进行反击。从击败柏林在线威胁的超级专业商店到扭转该国人才流失的保加利亚城市，从意大利城市寻找解决赌博成瘾的新方法到瑞典小镇找到了打击极端主义的创新方法，我们来看看在我们日益城市化的世界中，欧洲城市正在努力改善生活。 Martin Sebesta 于 2003 年创办了 Antstore，他对所在城市的宠物店缺乏专业知识或热情来告诉他如何建立自己的蚂蚁农场感到沮丧。在 20 多岁的时候从癌症中幸存下来，他放弃了在西门子有前途的职业生涯，并租了一家小店，在那里兼职建造和销售自己的蚂蚁饲养箱，他称之为“蚁巢”，取自昆虫的拉丁名称。 Antstore 的大部分销售都是通过公司网站进行的，但 Sebesta 认为这家商店本身仍然是其成功的关键。首次购买的客户可以选择任何东西，从包含健壮的 Lasius niger 或普通花园蚂蚁的 50 欧元（43 英镑）入门套装，到包含南美切叶蚁（一种切叶蚁）的三方蚁巢，起价为起价约 500 欧元。 “当然，你可以得到一条金鱼，看着它整天从左到右游动，”Sebesta 说，一群切叶工人在他头顶的玻璃天桥上勤奋地抬着一株枯萎的兰花的残骸。 “但是对于蚂蚁，我可以看到它们是如何从小事做起，然后做大事的。”他考虑扩展到竹节虫和蜥蜴饲养箱，但很快意识到向员工教授所需的专业知识可以扩展公司的能力。 “如今，如果您想将自己的头脑作为一家中型企业保持在水面之上，那么您不能不专业化。”
柏林-勃兰登堡贸易协会首席执行官尼尔斯·布施-彼得森 (Nils Busch-Petersen) 表示，大量超级专家的出现是历史机遇的结果。 “我们的城市拥有这些特殊类型的商店，不是因为参议院的努力，而是尽管有这些努力，”他争辩道。德国的 Mittelstand，粗略定义为拥有 50 至 500 名员工的企业，通常被誉为国家经济成功的“隐形冠军”，但在柏林零售业，中型企业传统上并不隐蔽而不是缺席。该市 9,000 家犹太人拥有的 Mittelstand 零售公司中有三分之二在 1938 年的帝国之夜大屠杀之后消失。1972 年，在冷战期间，东德甚至将拥有 10 名以上员工的小型企业国有化。在这样一个倾斜的零售环境中，许多小商店发现他们可以通过专门从事被多面手百货公司忽视的商品来竞争，特别是因为零售空间便宜且在铁幕后供应充足。 Bernd Moser 在 Kreuzberg 的 Gneisenaustraße 91 的商店展示了这一传统：76 岁的 Moser 自豪地留着白色海象小胡子，四分之一个多世纪以来一直只销售和修理打字机。尽管已经退休，但 Moser 在工作周的上午 11 点到下午 4 点之间打开了通往他稀疏房屋的玻璃门——主要是因为需求仍然很高。在从事了 60 年的办公机械机械师职业生涯后，Moser 拥有装满长期破产制造商备件的盒子，脑中仍然存放着大量使用说明书。 “拆开打字机是一回事，”他说。 “但我也知道如何将它们重新组合在一起。”拐角处一百米处是 Paul Knopf，这是一个横跨两个店面和几个存储单元的购物商场。它以其主人的名字命名，他本人以他 32 年来在柜台上销售的唯一产品命名：按钮，数以百万计，按材料、尺寸和颜色错综复杂地排列在抽屉里，一直延伸到粉刷天花板。 “我不知道这栋楼里总共有多少纽扣，”克诺夫说，“但我知道我死前卖不出去的纽扣太多了。”向东走一小段路，在 Gneisenaustraße 52，Harald Truetsch 近 10 年来只销售微型弦乐器：由木头或金属制成的尤克里里琴、带有塑料薄膜的“班卓琴”、曼陀林、南美卡瓦奎尼奥斯和小型低音吉他。 “大型音乐商店通常将尤克里里琴视为二流乐器，就好像它只是给孩子们的吉他一样，”特鲁奇说，他从柜台后面拿起自己的尤克，长长的白发飘逸。 “他们不会把小提琴称为儿童大提琴，是吗？”
Knopf、Moser 和 Truetsch 都在社区持续的高档化中幸存下来，部分原因是房东的宽容。但他们也以低成本运营精益运营——Knopf 有三名员工来帮助处理他复杂的归档系统，而另外两名则是单人秀。德国关于商店营业时间的严格法律允许他们独自工作而不会冒着倦怠的风险：许多超级专家不仅在星期天而且在星期一仍然关闭。在线零售商对其商业模式构成的威胁是有限的：Truetsch 的商店可能名为 Leleland.eu，但在浏览器中输入 URL 会绘制一个空白页面。当他尝试通过网上商店销售他的商品时，他发现邮政工作势不可挡（“对于乐器，人们想先试后买”）。在假期期间，leleland.eu 挤满了从远至阿根廷或以色列旅行的客户，与成人尺寸的吉他不同，他们知道他们可以在飞机上取回购买的物品。随着柏林超级专家的老卫士被证明具有惊人的适应能力，年轻的店主正在从他们的书中吸取教训。在熙熙攘攘的弗里德里希斯海因 (Friedrichshain) 的 Boxhagener Strasse，38 岁的服装工程师 Silvia Wald 在一家老肉店开了一家店，出售老顾客过去常在柜台后面看到的那种商品：猪腿、香肠链、意式香肠火腿、培根烤饼——但都是用织物制成的，用作装饰垫。这家商店是因为她的纺织公司 Aufschnitt（“冷剪”）的营销噱头。 “一根香肠生了另一根，”沃尔德说，具有讽刺意味的是，她从十几岁起就一直是素食主义者。她很快意识到店面是一个很好的陈列室，可以宣传在她 70 平方米单位的工作室部分进行的定制作品。在她的公司成立 10 周年之际，她也意识到专家有时可能过于专业化。最近，Wald 受委托制作一个咖喱香肠形状的巨型垫子，这是柏林著名的街头小吃。她的客户，德国首都杜莎夫人蜡像馆的分店，问她是否认识一位裁缝，可以做一些薯条作为配菜。 “我当然可以做一些薯条，我告诉他们。他们真的认为我只能制作看起来像肉的垫子。”超级专家通常会成为受欢迎的邻居，因为他们为一个地区增添了特色。自从 20 年前 Ilse Böge 在克罗伊茨贝格的 Gräfestrasse 开设德国第一家甘草专卖店 Kadó 以来，她目睹了整个地区的蓬勃发展。被称为 Gräfekiez 的绿树成荫的鹅卵石街道网络也吸引了来自世界各地的房地产投资者，当房东突然将租金翻倍时，这家商店的一些邻居关闭了。 “我们让这个区域变得有吸引力，现在我们可能会因此受到惩罚，”Böge 担忧道。柏林的 Die Linke（左翼）党住房参议员 Katrin Lompscher 提议扩大“环境保护”措施，该措施目前保护该市特定地区的低收入居民免受租金大幅上涨的影响，也适用到当地商店。但 Böge 在学习经济学时首先开始进口荷兰咸甜食以满足她的个人需求，她有两种想法。
她说，一方面，商店的环境保护将使小企业主能够稳定地规划他们的未来。但她心中的经济学家仍然持怀疑态度：“国家对未来 10 年零售业将如何发展了解多少？你最终会创建一个并行的业务系统。”相反，博格和她的丈夫弗兰克正在为后店面的未来制定措施。 Kadó 看起来很老式：500 多种甘草储存在玻璃罐中，从甜美的英式各种甘草到咸味的芬兰 Salmiakki 到苦味的意大利纯 liquirizia 棒，只收现金的付款通过老式收银机进行。但老派的外观背叛了更现代的商业模式。现在，这家商店多达 35% 的销售额是在网上进行的，而且 Kadó 的粘性糖果在柏林的大部分独立电影院都有出售，甚至在豪华的 KaDeWe 百货公司中也有名牌包装盒出售。柏林的第一位甘草专家会走与 Mohamad Ghouneim 的 Klebeland 相同的路线，这并非不可想象。 Ghouneim 是一名 40 岁的巴勒斯坦德国人，他从两岁起就把柏林称为他的家，他在克罗伊茨贝格的 Ritterstrasse 的一家商店经营着这座城市领先的胶带专家，直到租金上涨迫使他离开了这家店。 Ghouneim 没有关闭商店，而是搬到柏林郊区单调乏味的 Wittenau，并请了一些胶带艺术家来装饰新建筑的外墙。客流量自然减少了，但他 80% 的业务来自在线销售和常规工业客户，Klebeband 的四名员工为他们剪裁和配色各种品种的胶带。 “想象一下，你是一名舞台技术人员，你需要用胶带将一盏会变得很热的灯粘在一根柱子上，”Ghouneim 说。 “如果你去 [DIY 连锁店] Bauhaus，他们会不知道该怎么做。但是我可以告诉你，你需要一张聚酯薄膜，上面有一种特殊类型的硅胶，可以承受300度的高温。我的店里有一些普通人永远不敢梦想的胶带。 “试图向你推销一切的人越来越挣扎，”他坚定地补充道。 “像我们这样的专家就是未来。”

note_en:
O n the first floor of a nondescript 1,000 sq metre industrial unit in Berlin’s Steglitz district, four workers are cautiously placing pregnant queen ants into test tubes in order to dispatch them across Europe. This is  Antstore, the world’s first specialist ant shop, a business with around two dozen employees, a glass-cutting workshop, plastic and plaster modelling studios and a full-time  social media manager.
 It is just one of the surprisingly large number of shops in Berlin that sell only one thing, be it crawly insects, salty sweets, sticky tape or miniature string instruments. With online retail sales changing the face of high streets in cities around the world, many wonder if this hyper-specialisation could be more than an accidental side effect of the German capital’s tumultuous history, and also a blueprint for the high street of the future.
  As a series of crises puts Europe under strain, some cities are fighting back with innovative solutions. From hyper-specialist shops beating the online threat in Berlin to the Bulgarian city reversing the country's brain drain, from the Italian city finding new ways to tackle addiction to gambling to the Swedish town that has found innovative ways to combat extremism, we look at what European cities are doing to live better in our increasingly urban world.
 Martin Sebesta started Antstore in 2003, frustrated that his city’s pet shops lacked either the expertise or enthusiasm to tell him how to build his own ant farm. Having survived cancer in his 20s, he chucked in a promising career at Siemens and rented a small shop from which he worked part-time to build and sell his own ant terrariums, which he calls “formicariums”, from the insect’s Latin name.
    The majority of Antstore’s sales take place via the company’s website, but Sebesta reckons the shop itself is still key to its success. First-time customers can choose between anything from a €50 (£43) starter set containing the robust  Lasius niger, or common garden ant, to a tripartite formicarium with the South American  Atta cephalotes, a species of leafcutter ant, for a starting price of around €500.
 “Of course, you could get a goldfish and watch it swim from left to right all day,” says Sebesta as a trail of leafcutter workers diligently carries the remains of a wilted orchid through a glass skywalk over his head. “But with ants I can see how they start small and build something big.”
 He considered branching out into stick insects and terrariums for lizards, but soon realised teaching his staff the required expertise would stretch the company’s capacities. “These days, if you want to keep your head above the water as a medium-sized business, you can’t afford not to specialise.”
  According to Nils Busch-Petersen, CEO of the Berlin-Brandenburg trade association, the high number of hyper-specialists is the result of historical chance. “Our city is home to these special kinds of shops not  because of the senate’s efforts, but  in spite of them,” he argues.
 Germany’s Mittelstand, roughly defined as businesses with between 50 and 500 employees, may be commonly hailed as the “hidden champions” of nation’s economic success, but in Berlin retail, medium-sized businesses have traditionally been less hidden than absent. Two-thirds of the city’s 9,000 Jewish-owned Mittelstand  retail companies were lost in the wake of the Reichskristallnacht pogroms in 1938. In 1972, during the Cold War, East  Germany nationalised even small businesses with more than 10 employees.
 In such a skewed retail landscape, many small shops found they could compete by specialising in goods neglected by generalist department stores, especially since retail space was cheap and in plentiful supply behind the Iron Curtain.
  Bernd Moser’s shop on Kreuzberg’s Gneisenaustrasse 91 illustrates this tradition: aged 76, Moser, who proudly sports a white walrus moustache, has for over a quarter of a century only sold and repaired typewriters.
 Although already deep into retirement, Moser unlocks the glass door to his sparse premises from 11am until 4pm during the working week – mainly because demand remains high. After a 60-year career as an office machine mechanic, Moser owns boxes full of spare parts by long-bankrupt manufacturers and still has reams of instruction manuals stored away in his head. “It’s one thing to take a typewriter apart,” he says. “But I also know how to put them back together again.”
  A hundred metres around the corner, lies Paul Knopf, a shopping emporium spanning two shop fronts and several storage units. It is named after its owner, who is himself named after the only product he has sold over its counter for 32 years: buttons, millions of them, intricately filed by material, size and colour in drawers reaching up to the stuccoed ceiling. “I don’t know exactly how many buttons there are in this building in total,” says Knopf, “but I know there are more than I can sell before I die.”
 A short walk east, at Gneisenaustrasse 52, Harald Truetsch has for almost 10 years sold only miniature string instruments: ukuleles made of wood or metal, “banjoleles” with plastic membranes, mandolins, South American cavaquinhos and tiny bass guitars. “Big music shops often treat the ukulele as a second-rate instrument, as if it were just a guitar for children,” says Truetsch, his long white hair flowing as he picks up his own uke from behind the counter. “They don’t call the violin a cello for kids, do they?”
 Knopf, Moser and Truetsch have all survived the ongoing gentrification of their neighbourhoods in part because of lenient landlords. But they also run lean operations with low expenses – Knopf has three employees to help tackle his intricate filing system, while the other two are one-man shows. Germany’s strict laws around shop opening hours have allowed them to work solo without risking burnout: many hyper-specialists remain closed not just on Sundays but Mondays too.
   And the threat online retailers pose to their business model is limited: Truetsch’s shop may be called Leleland.eu, but typing the url into a browser draws a blank page. When he tried selling his wares via an online shop he found the postal work overwhelming (“With instruments, people want to try before they buy”). Over the holidays, leleland.eu fills up with customers who have travelled from as far away as Argentina or Israel, and unlike with an adult-sized guitar, they know they will be able to take their purchases back on the plane.
 With the old guard of Berlin’s hyper-specialists proving surprisingly resilient, younger shop owners are taking a leaf out of their books. On Boxhagener Strasse in bustling Friedrichshain, the 38-year-old garment engineer Silvia Wald has set up shop in an old butcher’s store to sell the kind of wares older customers used to see behind the counter: legs of pork, chains of sausages, mortadella ham, bacon rashers – but all made of fabric, to be used as decorative cushions.
 The shop was borne out of a marketing gag for her textile company, Aufschnitt (“cold cuts”). “One sausage gave birth to another,” says Wald, who ironically has been a vegetarian since her teens. She soon realised the shopfront was an excellent showroom to advertise the made-to-commission work taking place in the studio part of her 70 sq metre unit.
 In the year of her business’s 10th anniversary, she is also realising that specialists can sometimes specialise too much. Recently, Wald was commissioned to make a giant cushion in the shape of a currywurst, Berlin’s famed street food snack. Her client, the German capital’s branch of Madame Tussauds, asked her if she knew a tailor who could make some fries to add as a side. “Of course I can make some fries, I told them. They literally thought I could only make cushions that look like meat.”
  Hyper-specialists usually make for popular neighbours because they add character to an area. Since Ilse Böge opened  Kadó, Germany’s first specialist liquorice store, on Kreuzberg’s Gräfestrasse 20 years ago, she has seen the entire area blossom. Known as the Gräfekiez, the network of tree-lined cobbled streets has also attracted property investors from around the world, and some of the shop’s neighbours closed down when their landlord suddenly doubled the rent. “We made this area attractive, now we could be punished for it,” worries Böge.
 Katrin Lompscher, Berlin’s Die Linke (The Left) party senator for housing, has proposed extending the “milieu protection” measures, which currently protect low-income residents in select parts of the city from being pushed out by aggressive rent increases, to also apply to local shops. But Böge, who first started importing salty Dutch sweets for her personal cravings while studying economics, is in two minds.
  On the one hand, she says, milieu protection for shops would give small-business owners stability to plan their future. But the economist in her remains sceptical: “What does the state know about how retail will develop in the next 10 years? You would end up creating a parallel business system.”
 Instead, Böge and her husband, Frank, are putting in place measures for a post-shopfront future. Kadó looks old-fashioned: the 500-plus varieties of liquorice are stored in glass jars, arranged from sweet English allsorts via salty Finnish  salmiakki to bitter Italian pure  liquirizia sticks, and cash-only payments go through a vintage till.
 But the old-school look betrays a more modern business model. As much as 35% of the shop’s sales now take place online, and Kadó’s sticky confectionery is for sale in most of Berlin’s independent cinemas and even, wrapped in a designer box, in the luxury KaDeWe department store.
  It is not unimaginable that Berlin’s first liquorice specialist could take the same route as Mohamad Ghouneim’s Klebeland. Ghouneim, a 40-year-old Palestinian German who has called Berlin his home since he was two, ran the city’s leading sticky-tape specialist from a store on Kreuzberg’s Ritterstrasse until rent increases forced him out of the premises.
 Instead of shutting up shop, Ghouneim relocated to humdrum Wittenau, a suburb of Berlin, and got some tape artists to decorate the facade of the new building. Footfall has naturally decreased, but 80% of his business comes from online sales and regular industrial clients, for whom Klebeband’s four employees cut and colour match tape of all varieties to order.
  “Imagine you are a stage technician and you need to tape a lamp that gets very hot to a pillar,” Ghouneim says. “If you go to [DIY store chain] Bauhaus, they wouldn’t know what to do. But I can tell you that you need a polyester film with a special type of silicon glue that can stand up to 300 degrees. I have sticky tapes in my store that mere mortals would never dare to dream of.
 “People who try to sell you everything are struggling more and more,” he adds with determination. “Specialists like us are the future.”

title: 柏林的超级专卖店（2019）
